data.title: The HBCU 104 List: Best Schools to Attend in the South
data.meta_description: Top Historically Black Colleges and Universities to attend in the Southeast.
data.text:
The HBCU 104 List: Best Schools to Attend in the Dirty South

Top historically Black colleges and universities to attend in the Southeast

By BET Staff

Choosing an HBCU to attend is a big deal. Huge, actually. But before you start the process of filling out applications and writing essays, you've got to get down to the nitty-gritty, like picking a major and what school colors you'll look great in.

So, what can help you narrow down your selections?

Location.

Do you want to spend semesters near a beach or close to a bustling city? Would you rather stay in-state or get your education much farther from home?

From St. Louis to ATL to Philly, The HBCU 104 List highlights the best Historically Black Colleges and Universities to attend in the North, East, Southwest, and Midwest. This list will help you identify HBCUs near and far.

Let's dive into where you might want to enroll in the Southeast.

Alabama A&M University

Location (City, State): Normal, Alabama

Student Enrollment: 11,938 (Fall 2021)

Alabama A&M University (AAMU) was founded by a former slave, Dr. William Hooper Councill. It is one of the largest HBCUs in the state of Alabama. Alabama A&M University is known for excellence in agriculture, engineering (especially electrical and mechanical), and STEM education. AMU ranks in the top 3 of HBCUs in the nation for STEM production. The university's agricultural research and outreach programs benefit communities, while its engineering programs offer practical experience opportunities. Alabama A&M University offers 60+ programs with an international faculty, 50+ student organizations, and a prominent alumni network of change-makers in various fields.

Alabama State University

Location (City, State): Montgomery, Alabama

Student Enrollment: 7,928 (Fall 2021)

Alabama State University's 153-year history reflects perseverance, progress, and promise. Initially founded to provide education for black Alabamians, ASU has evolved into a thriving community and culture. The university boasts a lively student community, including fraternities and sororities. ASU's commitment to student engagement, community building, and leadership development is central to its mission. Located in downtown Montgomery, ASU offers students access to the city's vibrant business district, entertainment venues, art galleries, archives, museums, and historical sites.

Bishop State Community College

Location (City, State): Mobile, Alabama

Student Enrollment: 2,176 (Fall 2022)

Founded in 1927, Bishop State Community College (BSCC) is one of Alabama's oldest community colleges. It offers dual enrollment programs for high school students to earn college credits, features small class sizes, and has expanded its online course offerings for accessibility. BSCC is known for its strong focus on career readiness and boasts a high job placement rate, especially in vocational and technical fields. Notably, the college excels in its Aviation Maintenance Technology program and provides comprehensive healthcare education programs to meet regional demand. These strengths underscore BSCC's commitment to education, workforce development, and accessibility.

advertisement

Gadsden State Community College

Location (City, State): Gadsden, Alabama

Student Enrollment: 8,616 (Fall 2022)

Gadsden State Community College originated from the merger of several institutions, including the historic Alabama Technical College, founded in 1925 as the first state-operated trade school in the southern U.S. This campus now houses Gadsden State's technical programs, the One Stop Center, the Joe Ford Center, and the Alabama Technology Network. Additionally, Gadsden State offers a diverse range of student clubs and organizations across its five campuses.

H. Councill Trenholm State Community College

Location (City, State): Montgomery, Alabama

Student Enrollment: 3,692 (Fall 2022)

H. Councill Trenholm State Community College, situated in Montgomery, Alabama, is a comprehensive two-year community college. It offers associate transfer degrees, as well as associate degrees and certificates for workforce readiness. Beyond traditional education, the college provides opportunities for adult learning, personal development, and supports economic growth in central Alabama. Trenholm State boasts a wide array of student organizations, including fraternities and sororities, that enhances the campus experience.

J. F. Drake State Community and Technical College

Location (City, State): Huntsville, Alabama

Student Enrollment: 1,744 (Fall 2022)

J.F. Drake State Community and Technical College stands out for its affordability, offering lower tuition rates compared to four-year universities, making education accessible. The college provides a diverse range of technical and vocational programs, emphasizing practical, hands-on training for quick entry into the workforce. Its diverse student body enriches the cultural and social experience. The college's strategic location appeals to those wanting to stay close to home or seeking specific geographic advantages for personal or career reasons. Additionally, J. F. Drake State actively engages with the local community through outreach, partnerships with local businesses, and workforce development initiatives.

advertisement

Lawson State Community College

Location (City, State): Birmingham, Alabama

Student Enrollment: 6,188 (Fall 2022)

Lawson State Community College focuses on affordable, accessible, and quality education to boost student success and economic growth in diverse communities. Through innovative teaching, it readies students for transfers, gainful employment, and career advancement. The college also fosters student development through engaging activities that promote education awareness, social growth, leadership, wellness, diversity, financial literacy, and community service.

Miles College

Location (City, State): Birmingham, Alabama

Student Enrollment: 3,040

Miles College, a respected Historically Black College with Christian Methodist Episcopal Church ties, emphasizes the development of intellectually and civically empowered students through dedicated faculty. The college is committed to community service, reflecting the tradition of HBCUs, and its alumni network offers valuable career connections.

Situated in Fairfield, Alabama, Miles College provides a unique college experience in the vibrant Birmingham metropolitan area. Notably, their dynamic band has entertained audiences for decades. Miles College students have the opportunity to engage internationally, like participating in the Kakehashi Project in Japan.

Oakwood University

Location (City, State): Huntsville, Alabama

Student Enrollment: 2,904

Oakwood University, a historically significant Seventh-day Adventist institution founded in 1896, offers students a rich historical and culturally significant environment. The university's mission revolves around biblically-based education for service to God and humanity, with values such as respect, compassion, integrity, and service at its core. Students enjoy a holistic college experience, engaging in clubs, organizations, and sports teams. The university's strong commitment to community service and social justice initiatives provides opportunities for students to create a positive impact. Situated in Huntsville, Alabama, known for its aerospace and technology industries, Oakwood University's location is attractive to students aspiring to careers in these fields.

advertisement

Shelton State Community College

Location (City, State): Tuscaloosa, AL

Student Enrollment: 9,318 (Fall 2022)

Shelton State offers a range of academic programs that cater to different interests and career goals. Whether someone is looking to pursue a two-year degree, vocational training, or transfer to a four-year institution. Shelton State offers flexible class schedules, including evening and online courses, to accommodate students who have work or family commitments. Shelton State often collaborates with local industries and employers to offer programs that directly address the needs of the job market.

Stillman College

Location (City, State): Tuscaloosa, Alabama

Student Enrollment: 1,456 (Fall 2021)

Stillman College is celebrated for its outstanding academic programs, modern facilities, and small class sizes. The college excels in biological sciences, business administration, and teacher education, complemented by the esteemed Harte Honors College and pre-professional tracks in law and medicine. The college offers a rigorous curriculum within a climate of academic freedom, preparing graduates for careers, advanced studies, and global citizenship. Stillman emphasizes shared governance, fiscal responsibility, and innovative administration. Its students, The “Stillman Man” and The “Stillman Woman”, tackle academic challenges with confidence and character, while the college fosters an intellectually stimulating environment, nurturing spiritual, ethical, and moral development, a love for the arts, global awareness, and a commitment to the common good. This unique "sense of place" combines a private college's purpose with a historic mission, delivering an environment dedicated to intellectual excellence, personal honor, and societal betterment.

Talladega College

Location (City, State): Talladega, Alabama

Student Enrollment: 2,406

Talladega College was founded in 1867 by two former slaves, William Savery and Thomas Tarrant. Talladega College is one of the oldest HBCUs in the United States. It was established shortly after the Civil War to provide education for freed slaves. Talladega College, Alabama's first private historically black liberal arts college, has excelled academically for over 150 years. It consistently earns recognition, including listings in the Princeton Review's Best Colleges in the Southeast and US News & World Report's best national liberal arts colleges, HBCUs, and Top Performers on Social Mobility. Kiplinger's ranked Talladega College as the nation's second-best college for "low average graduating debt" in 2019. The campus blends historic and modern facilities, enriching the college experience, which includes a diverse range of sports. Nestled in a tranquil plateau 700 feet above sea level, it offers a peaceful academic environment close to neighboring cities teeming with cultural and entertainment options.

advertisement

Tuskegee University

Location (City, State): Tuskegee, AL

Student Enrollment: 5,308

Tuskegee University, established by Booker T. Washington, prioritized vocational education for African-American self-reliance. It nurtured achievers across civil rights, sciences, arts, and more. Designated as a National Historic Site, the campus houses the George Washington Carver Museum and Tuskegee Airmen National Historic Site, honoring their legacies. Booker T. Washington's final resting place is on the Tuskegee University campus, where he is buried alongside his wife, Margaret James Murray Washington. Their tomb is a significant historical site on the campus. In proximity to the university, the infamous Tuskegee Syphilis Study, a long-running unethical medical experiment, unfolded in Macon County, Alabama. This study, which began in the 1930s and persisted for 40 years, involved withholding treatment for syphilis from African American men without their informed consent, leaving a dark mark on the history of medical ethics and civil rights. Now ranked #3 HBCU in the nation, the university is very famous for its athletic team, the Golden Tigers, which competes in sports such as baseball, basketball, football, track and field.

Bethune-Cookman University

Location (City, State): Daytona Beach, Florida

Student Enrollment: 5,248

Bethune-Cookman University (BCU), founded in 1904 by civil rights icon Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune, Bethune-Cookman University is a thriving HBCU in Daytona Beach, Florida. The university possesses a renowned nursing program, a diverse range of academic offerings, and a commitment to community engagement. Bethune-Cookman's influence extends globally through international partnerships, while its cultural events and notable alumni enrich the university's vibrant legacy of leadership. Known as the Wildcats, BCU athletic teams compete at the NCAA Division I level, further enriching the college experience.

Edward Waters College

Location (City, State): Jacksonville, Florida

Student Enrollment: 5,742

Edward Waters College is a college with deep roots in post-Civil War education for African-Americans and is a vital part of the community. Affiliated with the United Methodist Church, it receives substantial support for its mission and development. Notable alumni shine in politics, business, natural science, education, and sports. The college's recent revitalization is adding a modern twist to its rich history, while cultural events keep its campus vibrant. Additionally, the college boasts a strong athletic presence, excelling in sports such as football and basketball while competing in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA).

advertisement

Florida A&M University

Location (City, State): Tallahassee, Florida

Student Enrollment: 60,310

Florida A&M University (FAMU) stands tall as one of the oldest HBCUs in the U.S., pioneering African-American higher education. FAMU boasts diverse academic programs, including a top-ranked pharmacy school and a renowned College of Law. The university's commitment to research extends to health disparities, environment, and agriculture. But it's not just academics; FAMU's Marching 100 band is legendary, captivating audiences nationwide.

Florida Memorial University

Location (City, State): Miami, Florida

Student Enrollment: 2,056

Florida Memorial University (FMU), founded in 1879, is one of Florida's oldest academic institutions. It has a diverse student body located in vibrant Miami Gardens. FMU’s campus hosts cultural events, displays strong athletics, and encourages community engagement. FMU's history and commitment to education make it a captivating place to learn and grow. Florida Memorial University takes pride in its legacy of notable alumni, among them are Trayvon Martin, who's tragic death in 2012 brought national attention to issues of racial profiling and gun violence. Complementing its academic excellence, FMU hosts competitive athletic teams known as the "Lions." These teams participate in a range of sports, including basketball, volleyball, and track & field, reflecting FMU's commitment to nurturing well-rounded student-athletes.

Albany State University

Location (City, State): Albany, Georgia

Student Enrollment: 12,594

Albany State University has a very impressive list of alumni, from the legendary Ray Charles to NFL champion Rickey Jackson, who have left their mark in diverse fields. ASU is a mixture of academic excellence, offering a wide spectrum of undergraduate, graduate, and professional programs, with a strong focus on education, healthcare, business, and Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics disciplines. Its location in Albany, Georgia, gives the campus a superb oasis, surrounded by a year-round warm and inviting climate. On top of academics, ASU actively engages with its community through outreach programs and partnerships. ASU Golden Rams, are a force to be reckoned with in NCAA Division II athletics, competing fiercely in various sports, including football, basketball, and baseball.

advertisement

Clark Atlanta University

Location (City, State): Atlanta, Georgia

Student Enrollment: 8,110

Clark Atlanta University (CAU) is part of the Atlanta University Center Consortium, which includes several historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) in Atlanta. This consortium allows students from CAU, Morehouse College, Spelman College, and Morehouse School of Medicine to cross-register for courses at any of these institutions. This collaborative arrangement provides students with a broader educational experience and access to a wider range of academic resources and expertise across these institutions. CAU is associated with notable alumni, including civil rights leader Ralph David Abernathy, author Alice Walker, and filmmaker Spike Lee. Located in vibrant Atlanta, it's a hub for academic excellence, cultural events, and impactful community engagement. The campus is steeped in history and houses the Robert W. Woodruff Library, a treasure trove of African-American heritage. With a strong Greek life, dynamic arts scene, and research opportunities, CAU offers a rich and exciting academic journey.

Fort Valley State University

Location (City, State): Fort Valley, Georgia

Student Enrollment: 5,846

Fort Valley State University (FVSU) in Georgia, founded in 1895, is a well-known Historically Black College and University with a rich history. As a land-grant institution, it's a hub for agricultural research and wildlife education. FVSU's scenic campus, famed Cooperative Extension program, and strong community engagement make it a vibrant center for both learning and community development. It's a place where history and innovation converge.

Interdenominational Theological Center

Location (City, State): Atlanta, Georgia

Student Enrollment: 474 (Fall 2021)

The Interdenominational Theological Center (ITC) in Atlanta is a historic consortium of five African-American seminaries, known for its civil rights connections and commitment to social justice. With a diverse student body, it promotes interfaith dialogue and community engagement while fostering a global perspective among its students and alumni.

advertisement

Morehouse College

Location (City, State): Atlanta, Georgia

Student Enrollment: 5,108

Morehouse College, founded in 1867 as an HBCU with a prominent history and notable alumni like Martin Luther King Jr., fosters strong student bonds. Renowned for its rigorous academic programs across various fields, it ranks #4 among HBCUs.

Located in Atlanta, Georgia, Morehouse offers access to a vibrant cultural scene and prestigious events like the "Crown Forum" and "A Candle in the Dark" Gala. Atlanta's thriving business, entertainment, and technology sectors provide abundant internship and job opportunities, to enhance the college experience.

Morehouse School of Medicine

Location (City, State): Atlanta, Georgia

Student Enrollment: 1,506 (Fall 2021)

Founded in 1975, Morehouse School of Medicine (MSM) is an institution with a mission to address healthcare disparities and promote health equity. It offers abundant research opportunities, emphasizing public health, biomedical sciences, and healthcare innovation for hands-on experience. MSM's commitment to community health aligns with its focus on community service and outreach. The school possesses notable alumni in medicine and healthcare who serve as role models. Located in Atlanta, Georgia, MSM provides students access to a dynamic healthcare ecosystem, including renowned medical centers and research institutions.

Paine College

Location (City, State): Augusta, Georgia

Student Enrollment: 502

Paine College offers diverse academic programs, including liberal arts, business, and STEM fields, providing students with varied educational opportunities. Smaller class sizes foster close student-faculty relationships and personalized learning. Located in Augusta, Georgia, the college grants access to a vibrant cultural scene, historical landmarks, and a thriving arts and music community. The institution's commitment to diversity and inclusivity enriches the educational experience, creating a multicultural learning environment.

advertisement

Savannah State University

Location (City, State): Savannah, Georgia

Student Enrollment: 6,770

Savannah State University's unique maritime program, complete with a fleet of training vessels, is a standout attraction for students interested in maritime and marine sciences. The university offers an array of over 75 clubs, organizations, and sports activities, providing students with diverse extracurricular opportunities. Additionally, Savannah State's commitment to affordability is evident, with over 90 percent of students receiving some form of scholarship or financial aid, making education accessible and affordable for many.

Spelman College

Location (City, State): Atlanta, Georgia

Student Enrollment: 4,834 (Fall 2021)

Spelman College was originally founded in 1881 as the Atlanta Baptist Female Seminary, and in 1924 became what is now known as Spelman College. Spelman is a private institution and an international leader in the education of women of African descent. Averaging over a 76% graduation rate for over six years. Spelman ranks #1 in Historically Black Colleges and Universities. The significance of Spelman is how the college focuses on the empowerment of the whole individual; intellectually, creatively, and ethically.

Dillard University

Location (City, State): New Orleans, LA

Student Enrollment: 2,404

Dillard University was founded in 1930 through a merger of two historically black colleges and has notable alumni like Marc Morial and Christian Scott. The university demonstrated resilience in rebuilding after Hurricane Katrina and is renowned for its strong arts and sciences programs. It also places a significant emphasis on community engagement and social justice in its rich New Orleans cultural environment.

advertisement

Grambling State University

Location (City, State): Grambling, Louisiana

Student Enrollment: 10,540

Grambling State University, a historically significant institution, was founded in 1901 and is renowned for its legendary football coach, Eddie G. Robinson, its exceptional marching band, and notable alumni such as Doug Williams and Willie Brown. As a prominent Historically Black College and University (HBCU), it offers diverse academic programs and hosts the annual Bayou Classic football game. The university also houses the National Black Sports Hall of Fame and is deeply committed to community engagement, making it a vital part of its local community and a symbol of African-American achievement in education, sports, and culture.

Southern University and A&M College

Location (City, State): Baton Rouge, Louisiana

Student Enrollment: 16,634

Southern University and A&M College, established in 1880 as one of the nation's oldest historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, is notable for its influential alumni, including former Congressman Cedric Richmond and Grammy-winning musician Alvin Batiste. Part of the Southern University System, it offers strong academic programs, particularly in engineering, nursing, and business, and engages in impactful research initiatives, addressing regional and national challenges. With a vibrant cultural environment and renowned homecoming celebrations, Southern University continues to play a pivotal role in education, civil rights, and Louisiana's cultural heritage while maintaining a strong athletic tradition.

Southern University at New Orleans

Location (City, State): New Orleans, Louisiana

Student Enrollment: 4,212

Southern University at New Orleans (SUNO), established in 1956 as a historically significant Historically Black College and University (HBCU), has a resilient history, notably recovering after Hurricane Katrina. Offering unique programs like Forensic Science, SUNO is deeply committed to cultural enrichment and community engagement. Its diverse student body, situated in the vibrant city of New Orleans, enjoys a rich cultural environment and opportunities for internships. Notable alumni have made significant contributions, and the university continues to reinvest and expand its facilities and programs, embodying a commitment to academic excellence and social impact.

advertisement

Southern University at Shreveport

Location (City, State): Shreveport, Louisiana

Student Enrollment: 5,490 (Fall 2022)

Southern University at Shreveport (SUSLA), established in 1967 as a community college, is a vital institution in Shreveport, Louisiana. Affiliated with the Southern University System and as a Historically Black College and University (HBCU), SUSLA offers diverse academic programs, including associate degrees and technical certifications, with a strong focus on workforce development and practical skill-building. The university fosters cultural enrichment, community engagement, and dual enrollment opportunities for high school students, while also supporting veterans and military-affiliated students. SUSLA's campus expansion and notable alumni highlight its dedication to accessible education, contributing to the educational and economic advancement of the Shreveport region.

Xavier University of Louisiana

Location (City, State): New Orleans, Louisiana

Student Enrollment: 7,208

Xavier University of Louisiana, founded in 1915, stands as the sole historically black and Catholic university in the United States, renowned for its exceptional academic programs. It particularly excels in the sciences and health-related fields, consistently producing a significant number of African-American graduates who excel in various scientific disciplines and health professions. Notably, its College of Pharmacy ranks among the nation's top programs and focuses on preparing pharmacists for underserved communities. The university places a strong emphasis on social justice, community service, and diversity, reflecting the rich cultural tapestry of New Orleans, where it is located. Despite facing challenges during Hurricane Katrina, Xavier's resilient community rebuilt and continues to thrive, contributing to both the academic and cultural vibrancy of the region.

Simmons College of Kentucky

Location (City, State): Louisville, Kentucky

Student Enrollment: 326

Simmons College is renowned for its unwavering commitment to social justice and active engagement with the community, addressing critical issues that affect the African-American community. Simmons College provides theological education that equips students for leadership roles within both the church and the wider community. Recently, the institution has experienced a remarkable resurgence, marked by a significant rise in enrollment and the expansion of its programs. These developments have garnered attention and acclaim for their commendable efforts to advance higher education within the African-American community.

advertisement

Kentucky State University

Location (City, State): Frankfort, Kentucky

Student Enrollment: 4,558

Kentucky State University is a renowned land-grant university, KSU seamlessly integrates classical education with a steadfast commitment to agriculture and mechanics, playing a pivotal role in nurturing Kentucky's agricultural advancement. The institution stands as a trailblazer in cutting-edge research encompassing agriculture, environmental science, and biotechnology, addressing pressing concerns such as sustainability and food security. KSU proudly celebrates a distinguished roster of alumni who have left an indelible mark on various fields, spanning education, politics, sports, and entertainment.

University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff

Location (City, State): Pine Bluff, Arkansas

Student Enrollment: 5,340

The University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff UAPB, is a land-grant institution, which means it has a strong focus on agriculture, agricultural research, and related fields. The university offers a wide range of undergraduate, graduate, and professional degree programs in various disciplines, including STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics), business, education, and agriculture. UAPBs athletic teams are known as the Golden Lions. The university has a strong athletic tradition competing in NCAA Division I sports.

Shorter College

Location (City, State): Little Rock, Arkansas

Student Enrollment: 490 (Fall 2022)

Shorter University offers a rich history of Christian education. It provides diverse undergraduate and graduate programs spanning disciplines like business, arts, sciences, education, and health sciences. The university's dynamic performing arts program enables students to participate in music, theater, and creative pursuits.

advertisement

Philander Smith College

Location (City, State): Little Rock, Arkansas

Student Enrollment: 1,420

Philander Smith College, founded in 1877, holds a proud legacy as a historically black college (HBCU), offering students a unique blend of historical and cultural significance. The college's strong commitment to social justice and activism resonates with students' passion about effecting positive change in their communities and society at large.

Arkansas Baptist College

Location (City, State): Little Rock, Arkansas

Student Enrollment: 828

Founded in 1884, Arkansas Baptist College aimed to provide education and vocational training for African Americans. With a small campus that encourages a tight-knit community and personalized learning, it maintains strong Baptist ties and affiliation with the Consolidated Missionary Baptist State Convention of Arkansas. Arkansas Baptist College (ABC) offers diverse undergraduate degree programs, including fields like business administration, criminal justice, education, and religious studies. Additionally, ABC has a sports program that allows students to engage in various athletic activities and competitions.

Alcorn State University

Location (City, State): Lorman, Mississippi

Student Enrollment: 6,148

Alcorn State University bears the name of James L. Alcorn, a former Mississippi governor instrumental in its founding. The campus is renowned for its charming landscape, featuring historic structures, lavish green areas, and the iconic Bell Tower. With a strong agricultural legacy, the university offers programs in agriculture, forestry, and environmental sciences, complemented by a practical farm for hands-on learning. Additionally, Alcorn State holds an Honors College that extends research and academic enrichment opportunities to highly talented students, and its mascot, "Brave," symbolizes the institution's historical connection to Native American education.

advertisement

Coahoma Community College

Location (City, State): Clarksdale, Mississippi

Student Enrollment: 3,122 (Fall 2022)

Coahoma Community College is located in Clarksdale, Mississippi, a city renowned as the "Home of the Blues" due to its rich musical history. The college places a strong emphasis on agricultural education, offering programs in farming and modern agricultural practices through the Charles W. Capps Jr. Technology Center. Situated in the heart of the Mississippi Delta, the college is deeply connected to the cultural heritage of the region, particularly the vibrant blues music scene. This heritage is frequently celebrated through a variety of events, lectures, and cultural activities hosted by the college. Additionally, the college boasts a distinguished choir recognized for its performances and contributions to the local arts scene, often engaging in community events and showcasing local talent.

Jackson State University

Location (City, State): Jackson, Mississippi

Student Enrollment: 14,160

Jackson State University has a multifaceted history, with both tragic and triumphant chapters. In 1970, the "Jackson State killings" marked a somber moment when police officers fired upon student protesters, resulting in the tragic deaths of two students and injuries to many others. Despite this dark episode, the university has an impressive list of accomplished alumni, including civil rights activist Medgar Evers, Grammy-winning jazz musician Cassandra Wilson, and NFL Hall of Famer Walter Payton. On a lighter note, the university's sports teams, known as the Jackson State Tigers, proudly bear the tiger mascot and excel in various sports like football, basketball, and track and field. Meanwhile, the famous "Sonic Boom of the South" marching band captivates audiences with its electrifying performances, even gracing major events such as Super Bowl halftime shows.

Mississippi Valley State University

Location (City, State): Itta Bena, Mississippi

Student Enrollment: 4,128

Mississippi Valley State University, known for its Delta Devils and Devilettes athletic teams, pays homage to its Mississippi Delta location through this unique nickname. The university can be proud to have educated alumni like Jerry Rice, a football legend who graced the NFL with the San Francisco 49ers and Oakland Raiders. Beyond sports, MVSU shines with "The Mean Green Marching Machine," a renowned marching band celebrated for its spirited performances. Moreover, the campus houses the B.B. King Recording Studio, honoring the blues icon and offering students a special opportunity to delve into music and recording. Further, MVSU's distinctive academic programs, including the "Birthplace of American Music," delve into the cultural significance of genres like blues, jazz, and gospel, enriching its educational offerings.

advertisement

Rust College

Location (City, State): Holly Springs, Mississippi

Student Enrollment: 1,536

Rust College, the oldest historically black college in Mississippi, proudly holds a rich cultural heritage. Its historic campus showcases buildings like the Leontyne Price Library, honoring the illustrious opera singer and Rust College alumna, Leontyne Price. The college's commitment to culture shines through its diverse array of events, including concerts, art exhibitions, and theater productions, which not only highlight the talents of its students but also contribute significantly to enriching the local community's cultural tapestry.

Tougaloo College

Location (City, State): Tougaloo, Mississippi

Student Enrollment: 1,426

Tougaloo College holds a significant place in Mississippi's history as one of the first institutions to integrate African-American students. Its picturesque campus, adorned with majestic oak trees and historic buildings, has earned it a spot on the National Register of Historic Places. The college's commitment to community engagement and service is evident through its partnerships with various organizations addressing local social and economic challenges. Additionally, Tougaloo College nests the Tougaloo College Art Collections, a repository of African-American art, showcased in the Ethelbert Barksdale Exhibition Gallery through rotating art exhibitions.

Bennett College

Location (City, State): Greensboro, North Carolina

Student Enrollment: 414

Bennett College has a remarkable alumni list, featuring notable figures such as playwright and author Pearl Cleage, civil rights activist Dorothy Height, and NASA mathematician Katherine Johnson, whose story inspired "Hidden Figures." The college's motto, "In Unity, There Is Strength," underlines the significance of collaboration in achieving common goals. Furthermore, Bennett College's historical significance is highlighted by its role as a host to several U.S. presidents, including Franklin D. Roosevelt, John F. Kennedy, and Barack Obama, all of whom have given praise to its campus. With a strong tradition of social justice and activism, the college actively participated in the civil rights movement, with its students engaged in protests and sit-ins during the 1960s.

advertisement

Elizabeth City State University

Location (City, State): Elizabeth City, North Carolina

Student Enrollment: 4,108

Elizabeth City State University (ECSU) features a renowned aviation science program with comprehensive flight training, preparing students for promising careers in aviation and related fields. As proud members of the NCAA Division II Central Intercollegiate Athletic Association (CIAA), ECSU's athletic teams, known as the Vikings, maintain a strong sports tradition, with basketball, football, and track and field ranking among their popular sports. Additionally, ECSU deeply engages with its local community through a robust commitment to community service and outreach programs. The university further enriches its cultural landscape by hosting diverse cultural events, such as concerts, art exhibitions, and theatrical performances, contributing to the vibrant atmosphere on campus and in the surrounding community.

Fayetteville State University

Location (City, State): Fayetteville, North Carolina

Student Enrollment: 13,496

Fayetteville State University's strong connection to the military is a result of its proximity to Fort Bragg, one of the largest military installations globally. This unique location has attracted many military personnel and veterans to attend FSU, where the university offers tailored programs and resources to support their educational needs. The university's mascot, the Bronco, symbolizes strength, agility, and resilience, making frequent appearances at sporting events and other campus activities. FSU is also celebrated for its commitment to diversity, fostering a vibrant student population, and actively promoting cultural awareness and inclusivity on campus. Additionally, the university embraces traditional festivities like Homecoming, complete with a lively parade, football game, and alumni gatherings.

Johnson C. Smith University

Location (City, State): Charlotte, North Carolina

Student Enrollment: 2,332

Description: Johnson C. Smith University, one of North Carolina's 11 historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs), holds a significant place in history. In 2008, the university welcomed then-presidential candidate Barack Obama, who addressed crucial economic and social issues on its campus. Additionally, Harvey Gantt, an alumnus of Johnson C. Smith University, made history as Charlotte's first African-American mayor and played a pivotal role in the civil rights movement. Beyond its historical significance, the university remains actively involved in community service and outreach initiatives, forging a strong bond with the Charlotte community.

advertisement

Livingstone College

Location (City, State): Salisbury, North Carolina

Student Enrollment: 1,780

Livingstone College, named after the renowned Scottish explorer and missionary, Dr. David Livingstone, stands as a testament to his legacy of exploration and commitment to ending the African slave trade.
